snippet: The competition between the two groups, first provoked by differing strategies in Syria, will be hard to stamp out even if armies can weaken the jihadists in the Middle East and Africa.
abstract: Terrorist attacks in Paris and latest attack in Mali expose growing and lethal rivalry between Islamic State and Al Qaeda; some analysts believe Al Qaeda's January attack on Charlie Hebdo spurred Islamic State to do something bigger.

byline.original: By ANNE BARNARD and NEIL MacFARQUHAR
byline.contributor: Anne Barnard reported from Beirut, and Neil MacFarquhar from Moscow. Nabih Bulos and Rukmini Callimachi contributed reporting from Paris, Liam Stack from New York and Hwaida Saad from Beirut.

lead_paragraph: The competition between the two groups, first provoked by differing strategies in Syria, will be hard to stamp out even if armies can weaken the jihadists in the Middle East and Africa.

headline.main: Paris and Mali Attacks Expose Lethal Qaeda-ISIS Rivalry
headline.print_headline: Supporters of Al Qaeda and ISIS Tangle Over Who’s the Deadliest

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
